stem: After reviewing the patient's chart, including the nurse's notes, vital signs, and immunization records, determine the most appropriate nursing action regarding vaccine administration and the primary reason for that action.
options: defer the scheduled MMR vaccine and consult with the provider
document the parent's refusal of the MMR vaccine and educate on potential risks
the patient has a fever of 101.5°F (38.6°C)
the patient is currently taking antibiotics for an upper respiratory infection
the patient has a known allergy to neomycin
the patient's sibling recently had a febrile seizure following vaccination
the patient's mother reports a history of Guillain-Barré syndrome

blanks.correctOption: defer the scheduled MMR vaccine and consult with the provider
the patient has a known allergy to neomycin

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 1400: Patient, 12 months old, presented with mother for routine check-up and scheduled immunizations. Mother reports patient has been healthy with no recent illnesses. 1410: Vital signs obtained. Temp 98.9°F (37.2°C), HR 120 bpm, RR 24, SpO2 99% on room air. 1420: Mother reports that the patient has a known allergy to neomycin, which caused a rash after a previous topical application. 1430: Reviewed immunization schedule. Patient is due for MMR and Varicella vaccines. 1445: Notified provider of neomycin allergy. Awaiting further orders. Patient is playful and interactive during assessment. Skin clear without lesions. Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. Abdomen soft and non-tender.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Alert and active infant.
Skin: Clear, no lesions noted.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Cardiovascular: Regular heart sounds, no murmurs.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, normoactive bowel sounds.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: No standing orders available. Awaiting provider orders regarding immunization administration.

rationale.correct: The MMR vaccine contains neomycin as a stabilizer. A known allergy to neomycin is a contraindication for administering the MMR vaccine. Therefore, the nurse should hold the vaccine and consult with the provider for further instructions.
rationale.incorrect: Administering the vaccine with a known contraindication can lead to a severe allergic reaction. Documenting refusal without addressing the allergy is inappropriate. Administering only varicella does not address the contraindication.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: The MMR vaccine contains trace amounts of neomycin. Administering the vaccine to a patient with a known neomycin allergy can result in a hypersensitivity reaction, ranging from mild skin reactions to severe anaphylaxis. Deferring the vaccine and consulting with the provider allows for further evaluation and consideration of alternative vaccination strategies, such as using a neomycin-free vaccine (if available) or referring the patient to an allergist for desensitization.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: Neomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic used as a stabilizer in some vaccines, including the MMR vaccine. Individuals with a confirmed allergy to neomycin are at risk of experiencing an allergic reaction upon exposure to the vaccine. Prioritizing the patient's safety by recognizing and acting upon this allergy is crucial in preventing adverse events.

clinicalPearls: Always review patient allergy history before administering any medication or vaccine.
Be aware of the components of vaccines and potential contraindications.
Consult with the provider when a contraindication is identified to determine the best course of action.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming that a mild reaction to topical neomycin does not contraindicate the MMR vaccine.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Recognize that any documented allergy, regardless of severity, should be considered a contraindication until further evaluated by a healthcare provider.

mnemonic.title: A.L.L.E.R.G.Y
mnemonic.expansion: Assess allergies, Look for contraindications, Listen to patient reports, Educate on risks/benefits, Reassess before administration, Get provider input, Yield to safety protocols.
